'Vanadyl(IV) sulfate', VOSO 4, is a well known inorganic compound of
vanadium. This very hygroscopic blue solid is one of the most common sources of
vanadium in the laboratory, reflecting its high stability. It features the
vanadyl ion, VO 2+ , which has been called the "most stable diatomic
ion." Vanadyl sulfate is an intermediate in the extraction
of vanadium from petroleum residues, a major commercial source of
vanadium. GÃ¼nter Bauer, Volker GÃ¼ther, Hans Hess, Andreas Otto, Oskar Roidl,
Heinz Roller, Siegfried Sattelberger in "Vanadium and Vanadium Compounds" in
Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Wiley-VCH, Weinheim, 2005.
Vanadyl sulfate is a component of some food supplements and drugs. Vanadyl
compounds mimic the effects of insulin, although humans seem to have no dietary
requirement for vanadium.
